awd_titl_txt: CS10K:CS1C@OC-Building a Local Area Network of Computer Science Teachers
awd_abstract_narration:
The University of California Irvine (UCI) project, called CS1C@OC, will provide in-service teachers
in Orange County (OC), California a program of study that will satisfy California's new teacher
certification pathway in Computer Science. Despite the demonstrated need for students to learn
foundational computer science skills, few K-12 students have access to rigorous CS courses. CS
remains privileged knowledge, and improving access to this knowledge is one of the major
economic security and social justice issues of the 21st century. The CS community has struggled to
overcome issues of access and equity, although some enormous strides have come in teaching tools,
pedagogies, and standards. But none of these accomplishments can be broadly implemented or
sustainable without certification pathways for CS teachers and teacher preparation programs,
especially for those teaching in underserved communities. CS1C@OC will develop such a CS
teacher preparation program, specifically for California's new CS Supplementary Authorization.

CS1C@0C aims to (1) increase in-service teachers' CS content knowledge and their competence and
confidence in evidence-based pedagogical practices for teaching computer science to diverse
learners; (2) increase diverse students' knowledge and skills in computational thinking and
computer science principles as well as their interest in taking more CS courses; and (3) increase the
capacity of Orange County schools to provide CS courses. CS1C@OC will recruit and train 100
secondary school teachers--our share of the CS10K project (OC has approximately 10% of the
nation's population)--largely from low-income communities serving underrepresented
populations, with preference given to teachers who, along with their school, make a commitment to
teach Exploring Computer Science (ECS) and/or Computer Science Principles (CSP). UCI will
provide summer courses in CS content and pedagogy that will satisfy the requirements for
California's newly-approved Computer Science Supplementary Authorization (which PI Richardson
proposed and developed along with the California Commission on Teacher Credentialing) while
emphasizing CS instructional approaches that have proven successful with females and students
from low-income, underrepresented communities. The project will also develop a hybrid
professional learning community (PLC) for participating teachers and including existing OC CS
teachers, so they can share information and experiences, continue to learn from each other, and
have further opportunities to develop themselves both personally and professionally throughout
the school year. The project will evaluate impact on teacher learning and development as well as
impact on student learning and attitude changes.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: Computer Science for All (CS for All)
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The primary goal of the CS1C@OC project was to develop a Computer Science Teacher Certificate Program and then prepare 100 (1C) teachers in Orange County (@OC) to successfully offer high quality, rigorous computer science (CS) while also broadening participation in computing. 100 CS teachers represent Orange County's contribution to NSF's goal of preparing 10,000 CS teachers (CS10K), as Orange County accounts for 1% of the nation's population, and 100 is 1% of NSF's CS10K goal. 

The CS1C@OC program was developed to prepare teachers to teach introductory CS primarily in high school but also potentially in middle school. Two of the target courses - Exploring Computer Science (ECS) and Computer Science Principles (CSP) - had been developed with the support of NSF specifically to appeal to students who are underrepresented in computing. Secondarily, the CS1C@OC program was designed to prepare teachers who need further qualification to teach computer science in California to obtain California's new Supplementary Authorization in Computer Science for teachers with a single subject teaching credential in any subject or a multiple subject teaching credential. The project also created community among Orange County's CS teachers through a Professional Learning Community and establishing the Orange County chapter of the Computer Science Teachers Association.

The CS1C@OC Teacher Certificate Program consists of four courses, developed and iteratively refined: Teaching Exploring Computer Science, Teaching Computer Science Principles, Methods for Teaching Computer Science, and Advanced Topics for Computer Science Teachers. This four-course sequence synergistically meets the requirements of California's Supplementary Authorization in Computer Science.

The CS1C@OC program was designed to improve teachers' confidence in evidence-based pedagogical practices, specifically for teaching computer science to diverse learners, as well as to increase their CS content knowledge and relevant skills. To expand the capacity of Orange County schools to provide effective CS instruction, the project recruited teachers broadly throughout OC school districts, and required a commitment by both teacher and school administration to teach ECS or CSP in one of the two years following their first year (two courses) of the CS1C@OC program. To increase diverse students' CS knowledge and skills, thereby broadening participation in computing, the selection criteria for teacher-participants prioritized schools with high populations of underrepresented minorities and/or high percentage of lower socio-economic students, as measured by their eligibility for free or reduced price lunches.

During the first four years of CS1C@OC, we successfully prepared three cohorts of in-service teachers, as planned. We accepted 97 teachers out of 301 applicants; 90 teachers started the program and 73 passed all four courses - an 81% average completion rate. The third cohort had a 93% completion rate, demonstrating substantially improved retention. Of these teachers, 24.4% were from groups underrepresented in CS, 9% were teachers with disabilities, and 40% identified as women. These teacher-participants taught in 41 schools with demographics that included 44.4% students underrepresented in CS, 11.6% English learners, and 47.2% lower socio-economic students.

Remaining funds permitted us to invite a fourth cohort; this cohort was pre-service teachers. Those who completed the program were qualified to obtain the CS Supplementary Authorization along with their primary credential. The authorization would enable them to teach computer science in California's public schools alongside their primary subject. 28 student teachers in the fourth cohort completed the program.

Over the five years of this project, our primary goal was met as 101 teachers successfully completed our CS1C@OC Computer Science Teachers Certificate Program.

According to the external evaluator's final report, CS1C@OC improved access to high quality CS education in Orange County and increased teacher-participants' self-efficacy and confidence in CS. The teacher-participants increased not only their CS knowledge and skills but also their ability to apply effective pedagogical practices. Teachers of all experience levels reported that the program contributed to improving their instruction. Students in their classes had positive attitudes and interest in CS and improved CS knowledge and skills as well as self-efficacy scores. The CS1C@OC program increased the number of OC teachers able to teach CS classes, the number of CS classes in OC, and the number of OC schools teaching CS.

The CS1C@OC project provided teacher professional development and made strides towards broadening participation in computing. Increased self-efficacy in both content and pedagogical knowledge empowered our teacher-participants to better educate diverse students. The program promoted equitable teaching practices that help close academic gaps among students from diverse ethnic, social and cultural backgrounds. Moreover, the teachers found the practices learned are transferable to their teaching in other disciplines. 

Computing affects virtually all aspects of modern life, thus CS education has broad societal impacts. Computers are used in domains as broad ranging as business and law, arts and design, health and medicine, military and manufacturing, amongst others. Preparing the next generation of young people to understand computer science and its impacts can thus have broad impact on the future of our society.


Last Modified: 02/03/2022
Modified by: Debra J Richardson
